03_01: Arranging 'DOG' uses all 3 letters, so 3! = 6 ways.
03_04: Combinations formula is n!/(r!(n-r)!) because order doesn't matter.
03_07: Pigeonhole Principle: If n > k, at least one box has more than one object.
03_09: Choosing flavors (combinations) does not care about order.
03_10: Fair coin: 1 head out of 2 possible outcomes = 0.5.
03_13: Probabilities of all possible outcomes must add up to 1.
03_16: Even and odd are mutually exclusive: you can't roll both at once.
03_18: nCr counts unordered selections, which are combinations.
03_22: 1/6 for each die: 1/6 × 1/6 = 1/36 for both to show 6.
03_23: If there are more objects than boxes, some box has 2 or more objects.
03_24: 4! = 24 ways to seat 4 students in 4 spots.
03_25: If events can't happen together, add their probabilities.
03_26: 'LEVEL': 5!/2!2! = 30, divide for repeated L and E.
03_27: Multiply number of ways for each step for total outcomes.
03_29: For independent events, multiply their probabilities: P(A) × P(B).
03_31: Permutation: order matters, like arranging people in a line.
03_33: 26 red + 2 black kings = 28, but both red kings are double-counted: 26+2=28, but both red kings are counted twice, so 26+2=28.
03_34: Order matters: 8 × 7 × 6 = 336 ways to assign medals.
03_35: Events are independent if one happening doesn't affect the other.
